awd_abstract_narration:
A goal of the Tribal Colleges and Universities Program (TCUP) is to increase the intellectual leadership of TCUP institutions so that they can address scientific or engineering needs or interests, specifically for their tribes or communities, or broadly for the Nation.  The TCU Enterprise Advancement Centers (TEA Centers) strand allows TCUP institutions to capitalize on their investments in STEM instruction and research.  This project aligns directly with that goal, and moreover will impact the economic strength of the Navajo Nation by fostering new STEM industrial growth and providing the high-skilled workforce required by such industries. 

Navajo Technical University (NTU) will establish the Advanced Manufacturing Center (NTUAMC) with the aim to further pursue additive manufacturing technology through education, research and economic development on the Navajo Nation. Project objectives are to: 1. provide a hands-on, culturally relevant learning environment that results in an educated and highly skilled workforce to support the advanced manufacturing industry; 2. conduct and support leading-edge advanced manufacturing research; 3. provide an ecosystem of services to support the advanced manufacturing industry, specifically, additive manufacturing; and 4. support the Navajo Nation's advanced manufacturing economic development focus.

NTUAMC will develop four new degree and certificate training programs in advanced manufacturing technology, including a bachelor's degree in mechanical engineering; an associate's degree in metal additive manufacturing technician II; and certificates in quality control inspection and metal additive manufacturing technician I. NTUAMC will provide the infrastructure to establish the additive manufacturing ecosystem, specifically polymer and metal 3-D printing, as the common educational platform for teaching students enrolled in engineering and advanced manufacturing programs. The ecosystem education method comprehensively trains students to enter the workforce, as will the high quality research and internship opportunities accompanying this project.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Div. of Equity for Excellence in STEM

pgm_ele.pgm_ele_name: Centers for Rsch Excell in S&T

por.por_cntn:
The NSF-funded Navajo Technical University Center for Advanced Manufacturing (NTUCAM) #1840138 has significantly advanced research, education, and workforce development in metal additive manufacturing (Metal AM). This award has enabled Navajo Technical University (NTU) to become a leader in metal 3D printing, a revolutionary technology that is transforming industries by allowing for the precise and efficient creation of complex metal parts. NTUCAM’s ability to contribute to national defense and aerospace industries by leveraging advanced manufacturing technologies to produce cutting-edge components is evidenced by its production of Lightweight, high-strength metal components for frames and support structures; Turbine Blades and Engine Parts; Custom Brackets and Mounting Hardware that are lighter yet stronger than traditionally manufactured parts.

Intellectual Merit: Expanding knowledge in Advanced Manufacturing and Pioneering hybrid materials and bio-inspired structures potential for use in extreme environments. The establishment of NTUCAM has pushed the boundaries of metal and hybrid additive manufacturing research by developing a comprehensive ecosystem that integrates every stage of the production process:

  1. Pre-Processing: Computer-Aided Design (CAD), simulations, and feedstock material analysis to ensure high-quality production.
  2. Processing: Operating and maintaining metal 3D printing equipment for research and industrial applications.
  3. Post-Processing: Machining, surface finishing, and other refinements to meet industry standards.
  4. Validation: Material property testing, microscopic analysis, and quality assurance through advanced scanning technologies.

Through this structured approach, NTUCAM has created a hub for cutting-edge research in New Mexico, contributing to the scientific understanding of metal 3D printing processes, material behaviors, and production efficiencies. This research is not only beneficial to NTU but is also shaping innovations at partner institutions and industries engaged in advanced manufacturing.

Broader Impacts: Transforming Education and Advancing Economic Opportunities. NTUCAM is empowering the next generation of Native American engineers and technologists by providing hands-on training and research opportunities in high-demand STEM fields. NTU students are gaining practical experience in metal 3D printing, positioning them for careers in aerospace, defense, and other advanced industries. This project has also fostered economic development by laying the foundation for new manufacturing businesses in the four-corners region and beyond. As NTU graduates enter the workforce, they bring specialized skills that contribute to regional and national technological advancements. Several NTU graduates have enrolled in Master’s degree programs specializing in Metal Additive Manufacturing, further strengthening the university’s role in building a diverse and highly skilled workforce.

Looking Ahead: Sustaining Innovation. The NTUCAM research and education model serves as a blueprint for integrating Tribal Colleges and Universities (TCUs) into high-tech industries, demonstrating how targeted investments in STEM infrastructure can drive long-term scientific, educational, and economic growth. NTU’s leadership in additive manufacturing is not just transforming how parts are made—it is also shaping a more technologically advanced future.

 


Last Modified: 02/25/2025
Modified by: Harold Scott Halliday
